ohm-law.title: Precision Resistance
ohm-law.description: Find the resistance that gives exactly 30mA current when voltage is fixed at 6V.
ohm-law.hint: Use Ohm's Law: I = V/R. If I = 30mA and V = 6V, then R = V/I = 6/0.03 = 200 ohms.
ohm-law.proof: I = V / R = 6V / 200Ω = 0.03A = 30mA. The relationship is inverse — doubling resistance halves current.

ohm-law.title: Power Budget
ohm-law.description: Keep power dissipation below 0.5W while maintaining at least 10mA current.
ohm-law.hint: Power P = V²/R. To reduce power, you can either lower voltage or increase resistance. But current I = V/R must stay above 10mA.
ohm-law.proof: P = V²/R. For V=5V, R=100Ω: P = 25/100 = 0.25W < 0.5W, and I = 5/100 = 50mA > 10mA. Both conditions met.

ohm-law.title: Exact Current
ohm-law.description: Achieve exactly 50mA current using any voltage and resistance combination.
ohm-law.hint: I = V/R. You need V/R = 0.05. So if V = 5V, R must be 100Ω. If V = 10V, R must be 200Ω.
ohm-law.proof: Any pair where V/R = 0.05A works. Examples: 5V/100Ω, 10V/200Ω, 2.5V/50Ω. The ratio is what matters.

projectile-motion.title: Precision Landing
projectile-motion.description: Land the projectile at exactly 30 metres using any angle and velocity.
projectile-motion.hint: Range R = v²sin(2θ)/g. At 45°, sin(90°)=1 so R = v²/9.81. Solve for v: v = √(30 * 9.81) ≈ 17.2 m/s.

projectile-motion.title: Twin Angles
projectile-motion.description: Find TWO different angles that give the same range of 25 metres at velocity 20 m/s.
projectile-motion.hint: Complementary angles (θ and 90°-θ) always give the same range! If one angle works, try 90 minus that angle.
projectile-motion.proof: sin(2θ) = sin(2(90°-θ)) = sin(180°-2θ) = sin(2θ). So angles θ and (90°-θ) produce identical ranges.

projectile-motion.title: Maximum Height
projectile-motion.description: Make the projectile reach exactly 15 metres maximum height.
projectile-motion.hint: Max height H = v²sin²(θ)/(2g). At 90°, H = v²/(2g). Solve for v: v = √(2gH) = √(2×9.81×15) ≈ 17.2 m/s.
projectile-motion.proof: H = v²sin²θ/(2g). With v=17.15 at 90°: H = 294.3×1/(19.62) = 15.0m. At lower angles, increase velocity.

titration.title: Perfect Neutral
titration.description: Stop the titration at exactly pH 7.0 (neutral point).
titration.compute: (() => { const vol = inputs.baseVolume ?? 0; const nv = 25; if (vol < nv) { const h = (0.1 * (nv - vol)) / (25 + vol); return h > 0 ? -Math.log10(h) : 7; } if (vol === nv) return 7; const oh = (0.1 * (vol - nv)) / (25 + vol); return oh > 0 ? 14 + Math.log10(oh) : 7; })()
titration.hint: At the equivalence point, moles of acid = moles of base. With 0.1M HCl and 0.1M NaOH in 25mL acid, you need exactly 25mL of base.
titration.proof: Moles HCl = 0.1 × 0.025 = 0.0025 mol. Moles NaOH needed = 0.0025 mol. Volume = 0.0025/0.1 = 0.025L = 25mL exactly.

titration.title: Buffer Zone
titration.description: Reach pH 4.5 without overshooting past pH 5.0.
titration.compute: (() => { const vol = inputs.baseVolume ?? 0; const nv = 25; if (vol < nv) { const h = (0.1 * (nv - vol)) / (25 + vol); return h > 0 ? -Math.log10(h) : 7; } if (vol === nv) return 7; const oh = (0.1 * (vol - nv)) / (25 + vol); return oh > 0 ? 14 + Math.log10(oh) : 7; })()
titration.hint: In the buffer region (before equivalence), pH changes slowly. Use small increments of base near pH 4-5. Around 20mL should give pH ~4.5.
titration.proof: At 20mL: [H+] = (0.1×5)/(45) = 0.011M, pH = -log(0.011) = 1.96. Actually around 22-23mL for pH 4.5 due to the titration curve shape.

titration.title: Indicator Sweet Spot
titration.description: Find the volume where pH changes fastest (steepest curve slope).
titration.compute: (() => { const vol = inputs.baseVolume ?? 0; const nv = 25; if (vol < nv) { const h = (0.1 * (nv - vol)) / (25 + vol); return h > 0 ? -Math.log10(h) : 7; } if (vol === nv) return 7; const oh = (0.1 * (vol - nv)) / (25 + vol); return oh > 0 ? 14 + Math.log10(oh) : 7; })()
titration.hint: The steepest part of the pH curve is at the equivalence point — exactly 25mL for equal concentrations.
titration.proof: Near 25mL, a single drop (0.05mL) changes pH from ~4 to ~10. This is the steepest region — the inflection point of the S-curve.

optics-bench.title: Same Size Image
optics-bench.description: Make the image form at exactly the same size as the object (magnification = 1).
optics-bench.hint: Magnification = 1 when image distance = object distance. This happens when object is at 2F (twice the focal length).
optics-bench.proof: When u = 2f: v = (2f × f)/(2f - f) = 2f²/f = 2f. So v = u, magnification m = v/u = 1. Place object at 2F.

optics-bench.title: Double Magnification
optics-bench.description: Make the image form at twice the object distance (magnification = 2).
optics-bench.hint: For m=2, we need v = 2u. Using 1/v - 1/u = 1/f, and v=2u: 1/(2u) - 1/u = 1/f. Solve for u.

optics-bench.title: Virtual Image
optics-bench.description: Place the object so the image becomes virtual (behind the lens).
optics-bench.hint: A virtual image forms when the object is between the lens and its focal point (u < f). Try placing object at less than 20cm.
optics-bench.proof: When u < f, (u-f) is negative, making v negative (virtual). At u=15cm, f=20cm: v = 15×20/(15-20) = 300/(-5) = -60cm.

reaction-rate.title: Rate Control
reaction-rate.description: Achieve a reaction rate of exactly 4.0 arbitrary units.
reaction-rate.hint: Rate = C * e^((T-25)/10) * 2. At C=1M and T=25°C, rate = 2. To get 4, you can double concentration or raise temp by ~7°C.

reaction-rate.title: Temperature Mastery
reaction-rate.description: Find the temperature that doubles the reaction rate compared to room temperature (25°C) at 1M concentration.
reaction-rate.hint: The van 't Hoff rule says rate roughly doubles for every 10°C rise. Base rate at 25°C is 2, so you need rate = 4.

reaction-rate.title: Concentration Effect
reaction-rate.description: Find the concentration that gives rate = 10 units at 35°C.
reaction-rate.hint: At 35°C, the temperature factor is e^1 ≈ 2.718. So rate = C * 2.718 * 2 = 5.44C. For rate=10, C = 10/5.44 ≈ 1.84M.

logic-gates.title: Universal NAND
logic-gates.description: Select the NAND gate which is known as a universal gate.
logic-gates.proof: NAND and NOR are universal gates. In our simulator, NAND is index 4.

flame-test.title: Copper Identification
flame-test.description: Find the element that produces a characteristic blue-green flame.
flame-test.hint: Copper (Cu) salts typically give a beautiful blue-green flame.
flame-test.proof: The characteristic emission spectrum of Copper ions results in a blue-green color in a Bunsen flame.

periodic-table.title: Atomic Number 11
periodic-table.description: Find the element Sodium (Na) by its atomic number.
periodic-table.hint: Sodium is an alkali metal in Group 1, Period 3. Its atomic number is 11.
periodic-table.proof: Sodium (Na) has 11 protons, giving it the atomic number 11.

microscope.title: High Resolution
microscope.description: Set the microscope to 40x objective lens for detailed cell observation.
microscope.proof: 40x magnification is common for observing plant cells like onion peel.

cell-structure.title: Digital Zoom
cell-structure.description: Zoom in to exactly 8.0x to examine the nucleus detail.
cell-structure.hint: Use the zoom slider to reach the 8.0x mark.
cell-structure.proof: High zoom allows better visualization of larger organelles like the nucleus.

mitosis.title: Metaphase Alignment
mitosis.description: Find the time step where chromosomes align at the equator (around 40%).
mitosis.hint: Metaphase occurs after Prophase. Look for alignment in the center.
mitosis.proof: During Metaphase, spindle fibers align chromosomes along the metaphase plate.

anatomy.title: Lateral View
anatomy.description: Rotate the model to 90 degrees to see the lateral aspect.
anatomy.proof: A 90-degree rotation provides a side (lateral) view of the anatomical model.
